questions.text: What is 3 minute target for spO2 in newborns?
You are attending a delivery. A 1200gm, 27 weeks gestation baby is born limp. After doing the routine steps, the baby is gasping. What should be the next step?

options.label: D
options.text: Start PPV with 100% Oxygen with Chest compressions

questions.text: You are attending a delivery. A 1200gm, 27 weeks gestation baby is born limp. After doing the routine steps, the baby was started on PPV. After 30 seconds of PPV, HR is 40/min. Which of the following should NOT be done?
If heart rate is not improving despite PPV in a baby, which of the following step is NOT needed?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase the pressure in 10-20 cm H2O increments

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase the pressure in 10-20 cm H2O increments

questions.text: A full-term infant with an estimated weight of 3 kg is apneic at birth. The infant does not respond to stimulation, and after 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation, the infant's heart rate is 50 bpm. The neonatology fellow intubates the infant and decides to give a dose of epinephrine via the endotracheal tube. Which of the following is an appropriate dose of epinephrine for the infant in this vignette?
What is the drug of choice in managing symptomatic bradycardia?

A 5-year-old girl is unresponsive, not breathing, and pulseless. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is being performed. The cardiac monitor reading is shown below. Which of the following interventions should be performed next?

options.label: C
options.text: Establish vascular access and administer epinephrine.

options.label: D
options.text: Establish vascular access and insert an advanced airway.

questions.text: What should be the shock energy for 1st defibrillation in Joules per kg for cardiac arrest in children?
A 2yr old child comes to hospital with tachycardia. Her HR=200/minute, and has respiratory distress. Her ECG shows absent P waves and QRS duration<0.09 seconds. What should be the next step?
What is the maximum dose of first dose of Adenosine in SVT in mgs?
What is initial dose in Synchronised cardioversion in children in J/kg?
A 2yr old child comes to hospital with weak pulses, and CHF. Her HR=200/minute, and has respiratory distress. Her ECG shows absent P waves and QRS duration<0.09 seconds. What should be the next step?
The lower limit of a normal systolic blood pressure for a child 1-5 years old as per latest Surviving Shock Guidelines is:
As per WHO, hypotension in areas without presence of ICU care is all of the following criteria except:
Which of the following statement is not true about Surviving Sepsis Guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Dopamine is preferred to epinephrine in shock in fluid refractory shock in children

options.label: B
options.text: Bolus of normal saline should be given over an hour

options.label: C
options.text: In areas with ICU care, total bolus to be given is upto 40-60ml/kg

options.label: D
options.text: In areas without ICU care, total bolus to be given is upto 40ml/kg

questions.correct_answer: A. Dopamine is preferred to epinephrine in shock in fluid refractory shock in children

questions.text: Which of the following is the first recommended method of feeding neonates born to COVID 19 positive mothers?
INCORRECT statement with regard to management of neonates born to COVID 19 positive mothers?

options.label: A
options.text: Stable neonates should be roomed in with their mothers

options.label: B
options.text: Neonates who require NICU admission should be given breastmilk once they are stable

options.label: C
options.text: Skin to skin contact should be avoided at birth due to risk of transmission

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of transmission is reduced significantly if the mother observes respiratory etiquettes while performing care giving activities for the neonate

questions.correct_answer: C. Skin to skin contact should be avoided at birth due to risk of transmission

questions.text: Which is False

options.label: A
options.text: The dose of IVIG in MIS-C is 2g/kg in continuous infusion over 12-16 hours

options.label: B
options.text: The maximum dose of ivIg used is 100g

options.label: C
options.text: The maximum dose of iv Methylprednisolone used is 1g

options.label: D
options.text: All children with MISC are treated with ivIg + iv Methylprednisolone

questions.correct_answer: D. All children with MISC are treated with ivIg + iv Methylprednisolone

questions.text: Which of the following is not a WHO criteria for MISC in children?
What drug would not be part of regimen in taking care of moderate to severe MISC?
All of the following are indications of LMWH in MISC in children except?
Which of the following vaccine is not used in children as per latest evidence?
Which of the following is not true about myocarditis post-COVID vaccine in children?

options.label: A
options.text: It is seen following BN162b2 and Ad26.COV2.S

options.label: B
options.text: It is common in male adolescents and young adults

options.label: C
options.text: Benefits exceed the risk of side effects of the complication in young adolescents

options.label: D
options.text: It was more common after the second dose than the first dose

questions.correct_answer: A. It is seen following BN162b2 and Ad26.COV2.S

questions.text: Which statement is true about the 2021 IAP Immunisation Schedule?

options.label: A
options.text: A booster of the injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is recommended at 4-6 years.

options.label: B
options.text: A uniform dosing of 15 mcg (0.5 mL) of inactivated influenza vaccines is recommended for all children older than 6 months.

options.label: C
options.text: The second dose of varicella vaccine should preferably be administered 3-6 months after the first dose.

options.label: D
options.text: Approves the use of Menveo vaccine in the 1-55 years age group. It reiterates the use of this vaccine only in special situations

questions.correct_answer: D. Approves the use of Menveo vaccine in the 1-55 years age group. It reiterates the use of this vaccine only in special situations

questions.text: Which schedule is not true about the IAP 2021 Immunization Schedule mentioned below?
questions.correct_answer: A. 15 months- MMR2, Varicella-2, PCV booster

questions.text: A newborn presents with purulent conjunctivitis and pneumonia. Baby has no fever and has normal activity. On the gram stain of the purulent discharge, there is no organism found. What is your diagnosis?

A 5yrs old male child presented to the clinic with h/o of recurrent infections. The child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in the kid?
The patient reports to have another 3 years old sibling at home, who is fully immunized as per the immunization schedule , what is the best measure to prevent it in the siblings of the case child?

options.label: B
options.text: Give full course of DPT vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing is required to be done

questions.text: Two girls in the same class one diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12 years old close friend is in fear of contracting disease. What advice should be given to her:

options.label: D
options.text: No vaccine needed as exposure has already occurred

questions.correct_answer: C. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about post exposure prophylaxis of neisseria meningitidis?

options.label: A
options.text: Ceftriaxone and ciprofloxacin are the most effective agents for prophylaxis

options.label: B
options.text: Rifampin is also an excellent agent for prophylaxis

options.label: C
options.text: Prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for medical personnel except those with exposure to aerosols of respiratory secretions, such as through mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, intubation, or suctioning before or in the 24 hr after antibiotic therapy is initiated in the index case.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither penicillin nor ampicillin treatment eradicates nasopharyngeal carriage and should not be routinely used for prophylaxis

questions.correct_answer: B. Rifampin is also an excellent agent for prophylaxis

questions.text: A 14 year old male is on chemotherapy for ALL. He presents with fever, cough and hypoxia. On examination, he is tachypneic with increased work of breathing. Breath sounds are clear on auscultation. He is started on cefepime, but hypoxia worsens needed mechanical ventilation. His X Ray shows bilateral hazy opacities. His BAL silver stain shows pneumocystis. What should be the next step?

A 30-week-gestation pregnant woman is seen at the obstetrician’s office for a febrile illness. Her symptoms include headache and joint pain. She has had routine prenatal care and no complications of pregnancy. Physical examination reveals the rash shown in figure. She asks how this illness may affect her newborn. Of the following, the MOST accurate response is that a likely sequela is

An 11-month-old female presents with a 3-day history of increased temperature, irritability, decreased appetite, and malaise. Although she was afebrile on the morning of presentation, her parents are now concerned about a rash that they report has been present for only the last several hours. On physical examination, she is afebrile and appears generally well. A blanching macular and maculopapular rash is present on the upper torso, face, and neck. A smaller number of similar lesions are noted on the upper thighs. Despite her relatively reassuring clinical appearance, a lumbar puncture is performed due to the presence of a bulging anterior fontanelle. The fluid is clear with zero WBCs, and no organisms are seen on Gram stain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical signs and symptoms?

A 16-month-old boy presents with a 48-hour history of subjective fever, cough, decreased activity, and decreased appetite. Findings on physical examination are limited to numerous small, irregular, erythematous spots with a minute, bluish-white center located on the buccal mucosa. Which of the following clinical findings is most likely to be identified in this patient within the next several days?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis associated with fissured, dry, cracked, and erythematous lips and cervical adenopathy

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple, small, maculopapular erythematous lesions involving mainly the hands and feet

options.label: C
options.text: A petechial rash on the extremities with prominence over the wrists and ankles and associated with edema of the hands and feet

options.label: D
options.text: Multiple, grouped, vesicular lesions (some of which have ulcerated) covering the tongue and buccal mucosa and associated with gingival edema and erythema

options.label: E
options.text: A confluent erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and associated with coryza and conjunctivitis

questions.correct_answer: E. A confluent erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and associated with coryza and conjunctivitis

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of rash and subjective fever. He takes no daily medications and has no known drug, food, or environmental allergies. On physical examination, he is afebrile and looks well. Bright red, erythematous, nontender patches are noted over both cheeks, sparing the circumoral area. A macular blanching rash also is noted over the extensor surfaces of the upper extremities. The patient’s mother is currently pregnant and at 11 weeks of gestation. Which of the following fetal complications is associated with the etiologic agent of this child’s rash?

A 14-year-old boy is transported to the emergency department following the rapid onset of altered mental status while waiting in the school nurse’s office for his mother to pick him up from school. Upon arrival, he is barely arousable and has a temperature of 104.2° F (40.1° C) and blood pressure of 80/35. There is a purpuric and petechial rash covering his lower extremities and trunk. A Gram stain following scraping of a purpuric lesion reveals numerous gram-negative diplococci. Further history reveals that the patient shares a bedroom with his twin brother. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for the patient’s brother?

options.label: A
options.text: Doxycycline 100 mg PO twice daily for 10 days

options.label: B
options.text: Rifampin 600 mg PO twice daily for 2 days

options.label: C
options.text: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160 mg/800 mg PO twice daily for 5 days

options.label: D
options.text: Cefixime 400 mg PO twice daily for 2 days

options.label: E
options.text: Amoxicillin 1 g PO twice daily for 10 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Rifampin 600 mg PO twice daily for 2 days

questions.text: Intussusception is complication of …………….vaccine

A neonatologist evaluates a male newborn with dysmorphic facial features. After examining the infant, the neonatologist suspects that the infant has Apert syndrome. Of the following, which is likely to be found in this infant?

A 4year old boy is seen for a health supervision visit. He has eczema and has had recurrent ear infections that required the placement of myringotomy tubes. He attends preschool, knows his letters, and can draw a triangle and a square. He is interactive during the physical examination His height is at the 30th percentile, his weight is at the 50th percentile, and his head circumference is at the 70th percentile. He can hop on one foot for 2 seconds and sing his favourite nursery rhyme. His mother reports that his father, paternal uncle, and grandmother have short stature, a large head, small fingers, and shortening of both arms and thighs. His father has been relatively healthy except for obstructive sleep apnea. His grandmother had stenosis of the lumbar spine and hearing loss. His uncle recently had a newborn son with a large head and short limbs who underwent ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion because of obstructive hydrocephalus Of the following the inheritance pattern of the disorder MOST likely seen in this family is
questions.correct_answer: A. Autosomal dominant with complete penetrance

questions.text: An infant is being investigated for persistent jaundice and has a systolic murmur consistent with pulmonary valve disease. Ophthalmological assessment reveals an anterior-segment abnormality. What is the most likely skeletal manifestation?
This boy has proximal muscle weakness, aged 6 years. What is your diagnosis?
This MRI image is taken from a bed ridden 7 years old boy. What is your diagnosis?
What is the treatment of choice for the boy in previous question?
What is the inheritance in the below shown image?
What is the inheritance of Coffin lowry and Aicardi syndromes?

A neonate is diagnosed with supravalvular subaortic stenosis. Upon examination you note hypoplastic nails, prominent lips, and a stellate iris pattern. Which of the following microdeletions is responsible for this neonate’s likely syndrome?
Which of the following disorders is NOT commonly caused by a microdeletion?

A 4 year-old boy is seen for a health supervision visit He was born at fill item to a 5-year-old mother. The mother reports that at age 30 years she underwent fertility treatments because of premature ovarian failure. The boy has delayed speech and can say only 10 words. He is very active and runs around the room during the entire visit. The mother expresses concern about his behavior, frequent temper tantrums, hand flapping, and biting his 2-year old sister. The family history is significant for bipolar disorder in the maternal grandmother and Parkinson disease in the maternal grandfather The family history on the maternal side is unknown. Of the following, the MOST likely underlying etiology of this boy s clinical disorder is
The inheritance of NARP syndrome is
What is the inheritance in the below shown image?
What is the inheritance of pseudohypoparathyroidism Ib?
..........% of Prader Willi syndrome are due to unimaternal disomy
A newborn has no cyanosis with oxygen support, mild retractions, audible grunting with stethoscope, reduced air entry and respiratory rate of 70/minute. What is the downe’s score?
A 27 week preterm, 500gms is born in your NICU. He has respiratory distress, silverman score 6. What is the first step?
What is the diagnosis of this child who presents with this rash and diarrhea?
A 1 yr old child comes with diarrhea for last two days. He is thirsty, drinks water well, is irritable. His skin turgor goes back slowly. What is your next step?
When can a child copies bridge from model; imitates construction of “gate” of 5 cubes; and copies cross?
When can a child handle spoon well; helps to undress; listens to stories when shown pictures?
What does the third line from below depict?

options.label: D
options.text: Post natal onset of short stature

questions.text: Severe acute malnutrition is defined by a
questions.correct_answer: B. Below -3z scores weight for height

questions.text: Children 6 to 59 months of age may be discharged from treatment when they meet either of the following anthropometric criteria :

options.label: A
options.text: Weight-for-height Z-score (WHZ) ≥-2 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Weight-for-age Z-score (WHZ) ≥-2 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Weight-for-height Z-score (WHZ) ≥-3 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Weight-for-age Z-score (WHZ) ≥-3 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Weight-for-height Z-score (WHZ) ≥-2 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

questions.text: Vijay is a 5-month-old infant who has been seen repeatedly by his general practitioner because of colic. His mother brings him to the Accident and Emergency department as he is having episodes of suddenly throwing his head and arms forward. These episodes occur in repetitive bursts. His mother thinks they may be something more than just colic, as he is now not smiling or supporting his head as well as he did previously. He was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and has no other medical problems. His EEG is shown in He has history of acne like lesions on his face and suspicious lesion in his ventricle. What is the best drug for him?

George, a 2-week-old male infant, presents to the Emergency Department with vomiting, diarrhoea and poor feeding. Investigations show: • sodium 112 mmol/L (normal range 133– 145 mmol/L) • potassium 6.8 mmol/L (normal range 3.5–6.0 mmol/L) • urea 7.8 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–8.0 mmol/L) • creatinine 30 mmol/L (normal range 20– 65 mmol/L) • blood glucose 1.7 mmol/L (normal range>2.6 mmol/L) • infection screen—negative What is the most likely cause? Select one answer only.

Salman, a 5-year-old boy, recently had a birthday party at his local farm. Since then he has had 3 days of diarrhoea. The loose stool had some blood in it. His mother is concerned as he is still not himself. He appears to be very pale and has not passed urine for 12 hours. He has no other medical problems and is not normally on any medication. On examination you note that he has pale conjunctivae. His blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. You decide to take some blood tests and get the following results: • Haemoglobin: 76 g/L; white blood cells: 14200/mm3; platelet count: 50,000/mm3 • Creatinine: 200 μmol/L (normal: 20–80 μmol/L) • Prothrombin time: 13 seconds (control: 12–15 s) • Activated partial thromboplastin time: 34 seconds (control: 25–35 s) What is the most likely diagnosis? Select one answer only.

A 10-day-old female neonate presents with vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, and signs of dehydration. On examination, she is hypotensive and has hyperpigmented genitalia with clitoromegaly. Lab investigations show hyponatremia (Na+ 124 mmol/L), hyperkalemia (K+ 6.8 mmol/L), and hypoglycemia. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the suspected condition?
A 2-week-old infant with known CAH is brought to the ER with lethargy, vomiting, and hypotension. Labs show Na+ 120 mmol/L, K+ 7.2 mmol/L, and glucose 48 mg/dL. What is the first-line treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: IV hydrocortisone, IV fluids with dextrose and saline

questions.correct_answer: C. IV hydrocortisone, IV fluids with dextrose and saline

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with failure to thrive, recurrent lower respiratory infections, and bulky foul-smelling stools. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflated lungs with bronchial thickening. What is the gold standard diagnostic test?
Which of the following best describes the genetic basis of cystic fibrosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Autosomal dominant mutation in the FBN1 gene

options.label: B
options.text: X-linked recessive mutation in the G6PD gene

options.label: C
options.text: Autosomal recessive mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7

options.label: D
options.text: Mitochondrial inheritance of CFTR gene mutations

questions.correct_answer: C. Autosomal recessive mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with CF is found to be homozygous for the F508del mutation. What is the most appropriate CFTR modulator therapy?

options.label: D
options.text: No modulator therapy is approved for children under 12

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with facial puffiness, cola-colored urine, and decreased urine output. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. Urinalysis shows hematuria, RBC casts, and mild proteinuria. Labs reveal low C3, normal C4, and elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy with nephrotic syndrome has no response to prednisolone even after 6 weeks. His renal biopsy shows minimal change disease. He has normal renal function. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

A 2-year-old child undergoing cardiac surgery is at high risk for AKI. Within 6 hours post-op, her urine output drops, but serum creatinine remains normal. Which of the following biomarkers would most likely indicate early AKI?

A 4-year-old child presents with failure to thrive, polyuria, and dehydration. Labs reveal metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, normal blood pressure, and elevated renin and aldosterone. Urinary calcium is high. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl with aHUS (atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome) presents with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and AKI. Complement studies show low C3 with normal C4. Genetic testing shows a mutation in complement factor H. What is the next best step?

A 6-year-old child with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets presents with bowing of the legs and poor growth. Lab tests show low serum phosphate, high ALP, normal calcium, and elevated FGF23. He has not responded well to phosphate and calcitriol supplements. What is the best next step in management?
